docs.snippet: LEAD: The paper industry, trying to counter gains by plastics in the packaging industry, is developing new kinds of containers that are not only cheaper than plastic but significantly extend the shelf lives of juices, soups, fabric softeners, cere...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The paper industry, trying to counter gains by plastics in the packaging industry, is developing new kinds of containers that are not only cheaper than plastic but significantly extend the shelf lives of juices, soups, fabric softeners, cereals, insecticides and many other products.

headline.main: New Paper Containers Extending Shelf Life

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The race is on to develop the complete telecommunications ''mailbox.'' Telephone companies envision a day when customers will receive voice messages, text from computers and facsimile documents in their own private file in a telephone-company computer.

headline.main: New Kind of Mail, New Kind of Mailbox

headline.main: Turning the Living Room Into a Concert Hall

docs.snippet: LEAD: Interactive displays, in which a customer uses a keypad and a graphic screen to ask questions about a product, have become an important feature in modern merchandising. But every once in a while they backfire....
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Interactive displays, in which a customer uses a keypad and a graphic screen to ask questions about a product, have become an important feature in modern merchandising. But every once in a while they backfire.

headline.main: Sometimes an Advance Goes Too Far

docs.snippet: Conducting his ensemble in a recent performance at Arizona State University, Arthur Weisberg paid attention to the strange-looking instrument alongside the flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano. The success of the music, an experimental piece c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Conducting his ensemble in a recent performance at Arizona State University, Arthur Weisberg paid attention to the strange-looking instrument alongside the flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano. The success of the music, an experimental piece called "Virtual Encounters," depended on a computerized apparatus that looked like an oversized pizza box played by a man with what seemed to be a pair of timpani mallets. Mr. Weisberg need not have worried. After the performance the audience's applause repeatedly brought the group back out on stage. During the fourth bow, the conductor leaned over to the pizza-box virtuoso and whispered: "We've got a hit. Let's take this thing on the road."

headline.main: A High-Tech Baton for Living-Room Maestros

docs.snippet: Droplet by tiny droplet, the world's largest single-piece telescope mirror is being formed at Corning's advanced products plant here, just a few miles south of the St. Lawrence River.   The mirror, which will be over 27 feet in diameter and weigh ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Droplet by tiny droplet, the world's largest single-piece telescope mirror is being formed at Corning's advanced products plant here, just a few miles south of the St. Lawrence River. The mirror, which will be over 27 feet in diameter and weigh 35 tons when completed more than a year and a half from now, is the main element in one of a new generation of ground-based telescopes designed to explore the outer reaches of the heavens.

headline.main: A Huge Looking Glass for Japan

docs.snippet: The "buckyball," a type of carbon molecule shaped like a soccer ball, may prove to be a highly efficient filter for separating gases, according to scientists at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M.   Buckyballs, which were discovered ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The "buckyball," a type of carbon molecule shaped like a soccer ball, may prove to be a highly efficient filter for separating gases, according to scientists at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M. Buckyballs, which were discovered in the mid-1980's, are hollow molecules of 60 or 70 carbon atoms that resemble the geodesic domes designed by R. Buckminster Fuller, the late architect and inventor. Technically, the molecules are called buckminsterfullerenes.

headline.main: 'Buckyballs' as Filters: Purer Gases May Result

docs.snippet: An ultrasonic device tiny enough to navigate the arteries of the human heart could one day help doctors do a better, safer job of removing cholesterol-laden plaque from blood-vessel walls.   The device, still under development, would aid cardiolog...
docs.lead_paragraph: An ultrasonic device tiny enough to navigate the arteries of the human heart could one day help doctors do a better, safer job of removing cholesterol-laden plaque from blood-vessel walls. The device, still under development, would aid cardiologists in performing a technique known as atherectomy -- the use of a tiny, high-speed drill to shave away arterial plaque.

headline.main: Ultrasound Guides a Drill To Unclog Heart Arteries

docs.snippet: Until recently, most important advances in communications have come from breakthroughs in computer processing and miniaturization: ever smaller and cheaper wireless telephones, satellite messaging systems for truck drivers and global paging networ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Until recently, most important advances in communications have come from breakthroughs in computer processing and miniaturization: ever smaller and cheaper wireless telephones, satellite messaging systems for truck drivers and global paging networks. But now, a growing number of researchers in government and industry are focusing on what may ultimately be a more revolutionary goal: freeing the world from the acute scarcity of useful radio frequencies.

headline.main: Seeking to Use More of the Radio Spectrum

docs.snippet: Employees of Bell Communications Research Inc. who wander into the snack room at a research center in Morristown, N.J., casually trade grins, waves and suggestions with their counterparts in Navesink, N.J., even though Navesink is 50 miles away. S...
docs.lead_paragraph: Employees of Bell Communications Research Inc. who wander into the snack room at a research center in Morristown, N.J., casually trade grins, waves and suggestions with their counterparts in Navesink, N.J., even though Navesink is 50 miles away. Sometimes the employees swap water-cooler chit-chat; other times, they hold formal conferences. The 8-foot-high Video Windows that virtually bring these distant groups into the same room are a product of a new technology intended to expand drastically the amount of data that optical fibers can carry. Optical fibers, the thin strands of glass that transmit information using pulses of light, are like huge water mains with only a trickle of water flowing through them, according to Anthony S. Acampora, a researcher at Columbia University.
